Editor's Preview
The Olympus Stylus 730 is an all-around solid ultracompact, with a weatherproof metal body that's appealing to the eye. Also appealing is the large, 3.0-inch LCD, which dominates the otherwise slim camera's back side. The 730 is a superlative low-light camera, with a high-sensitivity mode (ISO 1600), geared to capture good looking images when less is available. The camera's buttons self-illuminate when it gets dark, and the LCD is super-bright.
Specifications
7.1 megapixels 3x optical zoom / 5x digital zoom Weatherproof, metal body Auto focus JPEG file format ISO 64-1600 3.0-inch LCD display Lithium-ion battery xD-Picture Card storage Part Number: 225840 UPC: 050332158245 Release Date: Aug 30, 2006
Olympus Stylus 730 Comments&Questions ( write your own! ) Write a comment or ask a question about the Olympus Stylus 730: Kaitlyn (09/27/2010) My Olympus Stylus 730 keeps saying"zoom error"whenever i attempt to turn it on, and the lens stays open. Whenever i presses the"Menu"button, it will chime several beeps after and turn itself off again. I can't send it in to get fixed and my warranty is over. Any suggestions ? reply to this comment (by James DeRuvo—09/29/2010) I'm betting it's a battery issue. THis camera is near 5 years old and those LiOns lose capacity over time. Try a fresh battery and clean your contacts. if that doens't work, it's time for a new camera. reply to this comment (emmaaaaa—08/29/2010) Hi there,
I was taking a photo and zoomed in quite a bit and then my camera wouldn't zoom out again. I took this as the camera being frozen and just turned it off hoping the zoom would reset. When I went to turn the camera back on, I noticed that the lens had not closed when I had turned it off. Now when I turn it on, I can hear the shutter trying to open (even though it's already open) and then the camera beeps a few times and then the start up music plays and then the whole thing shuts off. The screen is blank and so I don't know if this is the 'zoom error' all you guys were talking about but it's really starting to get on my nerves! The only explanation I have is the fact that I traveled from Hong Kong (where I live and it is very hot at the moment) to Australia (where we are now in the middle of winter) and the camera received a shock from the sudden temperature change.
I've tried hitting the camera against my wrist, my hand and the table and the lens has still not budged. I charged it overnight and tried the reset button and still nothing. I'm now sitting on my camera hoping that the warmth will release the shutter but other than that I don't know what else to do :( As I'm on holiday at the moment I would really like to get my camera fixed ASAP! If anyone knows anything that may help (besides me spending thousands of dollars getting it serviced) please let me know! reply to this comment (Chris Weigl—08/30/2010) Can you hear the motor trying to work and failing? You either have sand/dust stuck in the lens barrel or the motor failed. Either way, you'll need to get it serviced. You can try blowing around the lens with compressed air but it's a longshot. reply to this comment (emmaaaaa—09/01/2010) Thanks for your reply!
I'm not sure if it's the motor - it sounds like the lens is trying to open even though it's already open if you know what I mean.
I was able to get the photos off my camera onto my computer, and plugging it into my laptop actually made the screen work and I can now see the 'zoom error' message.
I think I'm just going to go buy a new camera - I asked a few camera repair shops what they thought and they said it would be about $200 AUD to get it repaired, I can buy a brand new better camera for less. I'm going to steer clear of Olympus though that's for sure! reply to this comment HB (02/11/2010) While everyone had the ZOOM ERROR my 730 had a an open lens issue.
Bought a new battery at TARGET meant for a FUJI (it said that it would fit the Stylus 730 too) for $19.95 by Targus.)
When the battery was installed the camera would startup and after about 5-10 seconds would turn off with gentle music.
Well...I slapped the camera on my wrist a few times and all of a sudden a picture appeared again. What a relief...
I firmly believe that there is a mechanical linkage issue on the little door which protects the lens. A gentle jar has released the jamming.
I was already to return the battery and walk away from this camera. I want to buy a new camera on my terms not as quick replacement for a bad one.
Thank you for the tip folks. reply to this comment (by James DeRuvo—02/13/2010) Cycling the camera on/off several times is often a more gentle course of action. Forcing things can cause more problems than it solves. reply to this comment HB (02/14/2010) After cycling the camera several times I gave up..!
I wrapped it on my left wrist while holding it with my right hand.
If I would have knocked the camera on a table, I would certainly agree with your thoughts. reply to this comment hajgomz (03/28/2007) i have a problem with my Olympus stylus 730... i cant start it.... when i press the power on button, the screen appears ZOOM ERROR!!! what will i do? PLS HELP!!!! pls help me to solve my problem.thank you reply to this comment (Andrew Skinner—03/28/2007) Haji,
This sounds like a lens error. I would try coldstarting the camera first. Take the battery out and leave it out for about 5 minutes. Re-insert the battery and try to turn the camera on. If this does not work, try the reset button on the top of the camera. If this does not work either, I would get in touch with Olympus repair support ( olympusamerica.com/cpg_sect... ). Good luck.

can you please help me where to find a solution in my problem..please i really badly needed your help. thank u again. reply to this comment (Jeff—05/06/2007) Hello,

I sent this camera for repair and it returned, everything works again. Took 1.5 week. Send it to Olympus Canada, or two other US locations found from Olympus web.

So yeah, if I don't get my camera fixed...its gonna be a total downer :(! reply to this comment (Sara—06/28/2007) well i just got a call..and they said they won't fix it due to user abuse..claiming i dropped it when i didn't!!! and i spend so much time arguing with them too!!! gah!!!!!!!!!!!!!! reply to this comment (ali—07/03/2007) i have the same problem it says zoom error!! please help me b/c i paid alott for this camera:'( reply to this comment (by James DeRuvo—08/24/2007) I find zoom errors occur when the battery power is near depleted. I have also found that if you hold down the on button for a second or two longer it doesn't occur as often. But the key is to keep your batteries fresh. reply to this comment (ali—08/24/2007) thank you james i sent it off to get it repaired but if i have this prob again ill take ur advice:) reply to this comment (fD—08/28/2007) I had the same problem with my stylus 730. Even when the battery's fully charged, it still wouldn't open. I found that if you lightly hit it on your wrist a few times, the lens cover will retract as normal when powering it up (what an advanced technique, i know). reply to this comment (LN—07/01/2010) Thank you so much! I am in Ireland and completely demented trying to find someone to repair my Olympus u730, googled it and found this thread - the wrist thing didn't work but then I lightly tapped it on the table and ....a little miracle after months of recharging battery and turning it on and off....it's working!!
Whatever life I get out of it now is a bonus - definitely won't buy another Olympus - shame because I love it.
Thanks again! reply to this comment (Nar—09/03/2007) fD, you're brilliant. I can't believe I didn't think of that myself. I have sent my Stylus 730 in for repairs 3 (yes, 3!) times in the past 6 weeks (all under warranty). The last time the repair took longer because they"were waiting on a part"which sounds as if they actually replaced a defective part (the lens cover looks different now) rather than just gently whacking it on someone's wrist. We will see how long this works; but you know that if I get ZOOM ERROR again, I will be hitting it lightly (or not so lightly) against my wrist to see if I can fix it myself! Thanks for the tip. reply to this comment (Jane—09/23/2007) I also had the zoom error for my brand new camera. PIECE OF CRAP! reply to this comment (Sara—11/21/2007) same here LB...so instead I got fed up with them and just opened it up and fixed it myself... reply to this comment (SUBZRO—01/15/2008) I KNOW HOW TO FIX THE ZOOM ERROR PROBLEM, JUST AS U TURN IT ON HIT THE PART WHERE THE RESET BUTTON IS OR AROUND THERE A COUPLE OF TIME AS IT IS TURNING ON AND IT WILL GO BACK TO NORMAL, WORKED FOR ME! Andrew reply to this comment (sweetheart—06/17/2008) SUBZRO thank u very much, it really worked and I was very close to spend my money on fixing it.... reply to this comment (aimee—06/19/2008) ahh its so annoying!
ive been hitting it for about 30mins and nothins happened, the lens is open, but wont close, :@ reply to this comment (Easylistener—07/04/2008) I've had a look, and before trying the tapping thing, and possibly damaging things, my friends camera Mu 730 had the same zoom error, so I took out the battery and warmed it slightly till it was at room temperature or just above, it started immediately showing a full battery level. It's been a great camera, I'm even on the second battery. But now I'm getting this zoom error you're all talking about, so I decided to google it and found this great thread. before this, I tried tapping, hitting, slapping, whacking and slamming the friggin' thing (after all, I already gave it up for dead since it it too old to repair and there are better ones on the market today for the same or less price.) I even tried prying the lens closed with a fine tool. NOTHING! The lens tries to close upon startup and zoom error appears. I could break out the jeweler's toolset and open it up. Any other ideas?
reply to this comment (jake—05/03/2009) I'm a believer now too. I was using my Olympus Stylus 730 and zoomed in to snap a picture. Suddenly the camera froze. The lens cover would not close and the camera would not turn on. When pressing the menu button the screen would come on blue. After reading this post I removed the battery, cleaned the contacts and put it back in. When I turned the camera on I hit the reset button then gave it a sharp wack across the top with my hand and now it works like new. I tried less forceful slaps and that did not work. I had to strike it pretty hard with my hand. Like the others have said, don't give up. The lens cover must get stuck and needs a good jar to get it going. reply to this comment (Stephan—07/23/2009) OH man! What specifically isn't working? reply to this comment aprilallard (12/14/2006) I am looking for the best under $300 for capturing lots of pictures of my always-moving 6-month old...indoor and outdoor shots, although focused right now mostly on indoor. Just to let you know about image stabilization. It works only with the photo taker/camera itself, not the subject. If the baby moves, the camera won't stop the blurriness if it has a longer shutter time. On auto settings in low light, the camera will automatically keep the shutter open longer to adjust for the lower light. If you want to take a better indoor photo, you'll want a higher ISO range (over 1000). Something like the Nikon S7c ( digitalcamera-hq.com/digita... ) or the Olympus 730 ( digitalcamera-hq.com/digita... ) both go up to ISO 1600. The Panasonic FX50 ( digitalcamera-hq.com/digita... ) goes up to ISO 3200, and will allow twice as much light in, creating a shutter speed that is twice as fast as the 1600 setting in similar situations. This might even be a better option for what you're looking for. All of these cameras are under $300 and should provide enough resolution for sharp pictures. Good luck and happy shooting.

There is really no such thing as a digital camera with no delay between photos, but what you'll want to look for is one with a very short recovery time so that you can take photos almost immediately after each other. You'll also want one without much shutter lag- that is, the amount of time from when you push the button to when the photo actually snaps.
A few good ones to look at for those features are the Sony Cybershot T10 ( digitalcamera-hq.com/digita... )- or the T30 ( digitalcamera-hq.com/digita... ), which is a little more advanced and expensive than the T10 in other ways, but measures about the same as far as speed. These have about 1.6 seconds between shots and about .4 seconds shutter lag- this is excellent in the world of digital cameras.
You can also get into extremely high-end cameras- like the Nikon D2X ( digitalcamera-hq.com/digita... ) that measure something like .25 seconds recovery time. But I'm not sure what price range you're looking at.
Do keep in mind either way that when the flash is on, any camera is going to slow down quite a bit... a 1.6 second recovery time may become something like 2.5 seconds instead.
